intro: Crepis henryi, commonly known as Henry's mouse-ear, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of central Asia. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its small, composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine habitats, preferring well-drained soils and full sun exposure. Its leaves are usually basal, rough, and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are yellow and bloom in early summer. Crepis henryi is often found in high-altitude environments and is adapted to cold, harsh climates.
